#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Design a Marine Audio System
#Text=A marine audio system is a stereo system specifically designed for a boat .
#Text=Standard car and home audio systems are not appropriate for aquatic conditions .
#Text=Therefore , any audio system that is to be installed in marine vehicles should include protection from the elements .
#Text=Follow these guidelines to design a marine audio system .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choose a stereo .
#Text=Marine stereos have electronic parts that are coated to protect them from water , salt and the sun 's UV rays .
#Text=Consider the following when choosing a stereo for your marine audio system :
#Text=Size .
#Text=Most boats come with standard , in-dash stereo installation .
#Text=The size of your dash cut-out will limit the type of stereo you can get .
#Text=Installation .
#Text=You may opt to mount your stereo , as opposed to installing it in the dash .
#Text=Mounted stereos come with enclosures to protect them from the elements , and can be mounted in a location of your choice .
#Text=Power output .
#Text=If you want your boat sound system to produce high volume and rich sound , you will need to include an amplifier in your system .
#Text=Amplifiers have separate channels to connect each speaker , and come in a range of power output levels .
#Text=The more power , the clearer and louder the sound .
#Text=Large boats requiring more than 4 speakers may need more than 1 amplifier .
#Text=Decide which features you would like to customize your boat stereo system with .
#Text=Remember that upgraded features will cost you more , and that you have many to choose from :
#Text=Water proofing .
#Text=All marine audio systems are weatherproof , meaning the electronic parts are poly coated and UV protected .
#Text=However , not all systems are waterproof .
#Text=If you feel that your stereo might be splashed with water on a regular basis , opt for a waterproof faceplate with a sealed gasket .
#Text=Remote control .
#Text=You may choose between a wireless or wired remote .
#Text=Also consider the line of sight necessary for the remote control to communicate with the receptor .
#Text=You may need additional receptors that can be installed in a different location than the stereo itself .
#Text=Auxiliary inputs .
#Text=You need these for any devices you may want to plug into your boat stereo system .
#Text=Devices that are compatible with auxiliary inputs include mp3 players , DVD players and satellite radio .
#Text=iPod or CD changer controls .
#Text=If you want to be able to control either of these devices by way of your stereo face , it will need to include specific controls .
#Text=Satellite radio .
#Text=Some marine stereo systems include satellite radio receptors but , in many cases , you will have to buy a separate satellite radio system that is compatible with your stereo .
#Text=Determine the type of speakers you want for your marine audio system .
#Text=4 speakers is standard for most small to mid-sized boats .
#Text=However , you may choose to install more speakers if you have a large boat , or if you desire very loud sound .
#Text=Take the following aspects into consideration when choosing speakers :
#Text=Size .
#Text=If you are upgrading existing boat speakers , then the speakers you purchase should fit into the pre-cut speaker holes on your boat .
#Text=Otherwise , you may choose to cut larger holes for larger speakers .
#Text=Remember to account for not only the size of the cutout , but also the depth of the speaker .
#Text=Installation .
#Text=You may choose to install new speakers in existing speaker holes , or mount box speakers .
#Text=Box speakers come in enclosures to protect them from the elements and can be mounted anywhere you desire .
#Text=Speaker quality .
#Text=You have several choices when it comes to speaker quality , depending on the sound you want for your boat sound system .
#Text=Dual cone speakers deliver a limited range of sound frequencies and are , therefore , relatively inexpensive .
#Text=Coaxial speakers are 1 step up from dual cone speakers , providing limited low to high range frequencies at a mid-level price point .
#Text=Component speakers use separate speakers ( in 1 speaker box ) to handle each frequency , and produce high-quality sound .
#Text=Subwoofers handle only bass frequencies and are only necessary if you desire a big bass sound .
#Text=Power handling .
#Text=In order to avoid damaging your speakers , choose only speakers with a higher power handling capacity than the amplifier you will be using .
#Text=Determine the placement for all of your stereo components .
#Text=Once you choose the components of your marine audio system , you will need to decide where to put the stereo , the amplifier , any special features that need to be installed and the speakers .
#Text=Make sure you account for ease of access .
#Text=Tips
#Text=A marine audio system may also be used for land-based applications , such as pool and hot tub areas and open off-road vehicles .
